rule.name: too CARDINAL NUMBER

rule.name: too DETERMINER

rule.example: We expanded too all proposed new locations.
We expanded too all the proposed new locations.
Give the bone too the dog.
We expanded to all proposed new locations.
Too much information is as bad as not enough information.
LanguageTool users can be annoyed if they get too many incorrect warnings.
How I wish that I'd gone with her too all those years ago. [Missing comma between 'too' and 'all'.]
The company is expanding too dozens of new locations.

rule.name: Th (The/thorium)
rule.example: Th water is hot.
Th usually busy train was remarkably empty today.
... but if Th water is hot, stop the test.

Th thorium was contaminated.
Thorium (Th) has the atomic number 90.
... but elements such as Al, Th, Mg and Nb are ...
... but thorium (Th) and the related ...
Th is the chemical symbol for thorium.
The chemical symbol for Thorium is Th.
Th contaminated thorium caused a problem.
These elements (Al, Cd, Th) are ...
Th was found in the sample.
Th must not...
Th usually produces 220Ra and actinium as the principal decay products.

rule.name: 'hair' + singular verb
rule.example: She cut her hairs yesterday.
rule.message: 'Hair'头发是一个不可数名词: 当你要说某人的头发时，要用单数 来表示一个整体。

rule.name: Let + object
rule.example: Let she do it!
rule.message: 请检查这里是否需要宾格形式。

rule.name: ask + object (no preposition)
rule.message: The verb 'to someone' does not require a preposition.
rule.example: She asked to me whether I like cats.
She was asked to the party.
I have to tell to them the truth.

rule.name: please + 3rd person verb
rule.message: Did you mean ?
rule.example: Please answers quickly!

rule.name: will follows be ('he is would')
rule.example: How is would this approach be useful?

rule.example: I rely my family to help me out.

rule.name: Missing preposition: allow (to) do
rule.example: He allowed me do it on my own.
rule.message: 请检查这里是否少了一个‘to’。）

rule.name: Missing preposition: explain (to)

They are important as pheromones, chemical messenger materials, on which insects depend for communication.

rule.message: 动词短语‘毕业于’要加介词‘from’: \1 from .

rule.name: all/most/some (of) + noun
rule.message: Consider using \1 or \1 of the \3.

Sometimes I go out for lunch, but most of time I bring my own lunch to work.

example.correction: all of a sudden|all of the sudden

rule.example: Where did this confidence appear from all of sudden?

Who know's?

rule.name: missing verb after 'if there'

rule.name: do you what (do you know what)

rule.name: missing verb (can what / can see what)

rule.name: objective case after with(out)/at/to/...

example.correction: to me|to her|to him|to us|to them

rule.example: Give it to I.

example.correction: with me|with her|with him|with us|with them

rule.example: Come with I.
I feel safe with him.
Look at her!

rule.message: 你是说 \1 me , \1 her , \1 him , \1 us , or \1 them 吗?

rule.name: possessivee case after with(out)/at/in/to/...

example.correction: at my|at her|at his|at our|at their

rule.message: The verb '\1' is used with the gerund form: .
rule.example: I enjoy to run.
I enjoy running.
A three-man committee has recommended to Commission Chairman Charles O. Emmerich...

rule.message: The verb '\1' is used with the gerund form: .
rule.example: I regret to read this book.
I regret reading this book.
I regret saying this.
Dear Madam, I regret to say that you are dead.

rule.message: The verb '\1' is used with the gerund form: .
rule.example: I consider to run my favourite sport.
I consider running my favourite sport.
They were a vagabond lot and considered to be shady and undesirable characters.

rule.message: The verb '\1' is used with the gerund form: .
rule.example: I am accustomed to run.
I am accustomed to running.
I am accustomed to hearing nonsense.

rule.message: In the grammatical structure 'pronoun + be/get + used + to + verb', the verb '\3' is used with the gerund: .
rule.example: I am used to run. I run every day for 30 minutes.
I used to run every day, but I hurt my knee. Now, I cannot run.
I am used to running.
I used to enjoy running.
When used with the infinitive, however, these verbs can be used to speak about something that hasn't happened yet.

rule.message: In the grammatical structure 'pronoun + be/get + used + to + verb', the verb '\4' is used with the gerund: .
rule.example: I'm used to run. I run every day for 30 minutes.
I used to run every day, but I hurt my knee. Now, I cannot run.
I used to enjoy running.
When used with the infinitive, however, these verbs can be used to speak about something that hasn't happened yet.

rule.message: In the grammatical structure 'look + forward + to + verb', the verb '\3' is used with the gerund: .
rule.example: I look forward to see you.
I look forward to seeing you.
But he was looking forward to snow.

No credit is almost as bad as bad credit.
He accuses the public health lobby of being just as big as big business.
rule.message: 这个短语重复了。你应该只留下 \1 \2 .

rule.name: according to
rule.example: According about a recent survey, most smokers suffer from cancer.
He was acquitted, because he was innocent according in the Jury.
According to a recent survey, most smokers suffer from cancer.
He was acquitted, because he was innocent according to the Jury.
We breathe life into this prized democratic value by according the Chief Justice due process of law.
'According as' is a conjuction (Merriam-Webster's Collegiate Dictionary, 10th edition).
'Accord with' is a verb, but it is not usually used in the progressive.
His system had eleven grades, arranged according "to the degree to which they are infected ..."
The manager was according him the greatest of privileges.
rule.message: 你是想说: according to 吗? according to:按照(as stated如上所述/in the opinion of据某观点)

rule.name: Wrong phrase: have x years old (be x years old)
rule.message: This phrase is used with 'be': be .
rule.example: I am 25 years old.
He has 25 years old.

rule.name: Wrong phrase: 'in nowadays' (nowadays)
rule.example: In nowadays, many organizations are jumping in the social websites bandwagon.
Nowadays, many organizations are jumping in the social websites bandwagon
rule.message: \2不和'in'连用。只用: \2 .

rule.example: He feels inferior than us.
rule.message: 形容词 \1 通常与 to 连用。

rule.example: He feels more inferior than us.
He feels inferior to them.
rule.message: 形容词 \1 通常与 to 连用。

rule.name: Wrong preposition: 'obvious for' (obvious to)
rule.example: It's obvious for me.
rule.message: 形容词 \1 通常与'to'连用: \1 to \3 .

rule.name: Wrong phrase: 'today morning' (this morning)
rule.example: I'm going home today evening.
rule.message: 这是一个不规范的搭配。通常情况下，要用this \2 。

rule.name: Wrong phrase: 'yesterday night' (last night)
rule.example: I was there yesterday night.
rule.message: 这是一个不规范的搭配。通常情况下，要用 last night 。

rule.name: Wrong phrase: 'today night' (tonight)
rule.example: I'm going fishing today night.
rule.message: 这是一个不规范的搭配。通常情况下，要用 tonight 。

rule.name: Wrong collocation: 'worry for' (worry about)
rule.example: Don't worry for.
I am worried about her.
rule.message: 动词'worry'通常不接介词'for'。你是想说 \1 about 吗?

rule.name: a sinking (s)hip
rule.example: The idiom 'like rats fleeing a sinking hip is used in reference to people abandoning an enterprise once it seems likely to fail.
rule.message: 你是想说ship吗?

rule.name: Collocation: apply to/for
rule.message: You can apply to a company or university, but you apply for \4. Revise: \1 for \5.
rule.example: You can apply to welfare.
You can apply to the job online.
You can apply to more assistance.

rule.name: Collocation: apply for/to
rule.message: You can apply for a job or welfare, but you apply to a \4. Revise: \1 to \3 \4.
rule.example: You try and apply for another University!

rule.name: Collocation: Sit in/at
rule.message: The usual preposition for activities with a desk is "at." Try this: \1 \2 at \4 \5.
rule.example: At lunch, I eat with my colleague working or I eat in my desk alone.

rule.name: Collocation: Between ... to/and ...
rule.message: Use "between" + "and" not "to." Try this: \1 \2 and \4.
rule.example: Children between three to five are cute.
...aspen parkland, a biome transitional between prairie to the south and boreal forest to the north.
...causing the electrostatic interactions between them to be strong.

rule.name: Collocation: Well in/on
rule.message: Use "\2 on" with "\4". Try this: \1 \2 on \4.
rule.example: I do badly in tests because I'm lazy.

rule.name: Collocation: Admitted at/to
rule.message: The usual collocation for "admit" is "to"," not "at." It is better to say this: \1 to \3 \4.
rule.example: On his way to an interview to be admitted at Princeton College, Quentin and his childhood best friend James arrive on a crime scene where they find the corpse of the man who was supposed to interview the former, along with a very nonchalant paramedic.

rule.name: Collocation: Summon at/to
rule.message: The usual collocation is "summon to" a place, or "summon at" a time/moment. Use "to" instead: \1 to \3 \6.
rule.example: Without him knowing, Quentin was summoned at an examination in order to get his admission to this institution.
Without him knowing, Quentin was summoned at a particular examination in order to get his admission to this institution.

example.correction: summoned to a very particular examination

rule.example: Without him knowing, Quentin was summoned at a very particular examination in order to get his admission to this institution.

rule.name: Collocation: in/on the Internet
rule.message: The usual collocation for technology is "on," not "in." It is better to say this: on the \3.
rule.example: Land reclamation is in the internet.

rule.name: Collocation: accompany with/by
rule.message: The usual collocation for "accompany" is "by," not "with." It is better to say this: \1 by.
rule.example: Land reclamation is always accompany with pollution.

rule.name: Collocation: Popular among/with
rule.message: The usual collocation for "popular" is "with," not "among." It is better to say this: popular with.
rule.example: John's popular among his friends.

rule.name: Collocation: Play with/for
rule.message: Use "for" with "play." You probably meant this: \1 for.
rule.example: He plays regularly with that team.

rule.name: Collocation: Opposite from/to
rule.message: Use "to" with "opposite." You probably meant this: \1 to \3.
rule.example: Their house is opposite from ours.

rule.name: Collocation: Marry with/to
rule.message: Use "to" with "marry." You probably meant this: \1 to.
rule.example: Angela was married with a rich man.

rule.name: Collocation: Prefer over/to
rule.message: Use "to" with "prefer." You probably meant this: \1 \2 to \4.
rule.example: She much prefers overalls over skirts, because she enjoys playing in the mud

rule.name: Collocation: Talk at/to
rule.message: Talking at someone means they aren't listening. You probably meant this: \1 to \3 or \1 with \3.
rule.example: I was talking at Charles about

rule.name: Collocation: Stress out for/over
rule.message: The usual preposition in this context is "over" or "about." Revise: \1 \2 over \4 or \1 \2 about \4.

example.correction: stressing out over everything|stressing out about everything

rule.example: I have to stop stressing out for everything.

rule.name: Collocation: Tired of/from
rule.message: The usual preposition in this context is "from." Revise: tired from last night.
rule.example: I am always tired of the last night

rule.name: Collocation: Repercussion with/on
rule.message: The usual preposition for "repercussion" is "on" not "with". Revise: \1 on.
rule.example: This action has repercussions with the entire community.

rule.name: Collocation: Look at/to
rule.message: The usual preposition for "mirror" is "in" not "at". Revise: \1 in a mirror.
rule.example: I suppose what makes me unusual is the fact that I can put on make up without looking at a mirror.

rule.name: Collocation: Passionate by/about
rule.message: The usual preposition for "passionate" is "about" not "by". Revise: passionate about.
rule.example: I am very passionated by my job.

rule.name: Collocation: passionate by/about (stricter)
rule.message: The usual preposition for "passionate" is "about" not "by". Revise: \1 passionate about or \1 inspired by.
rule.example: I'm really passionate by the chocolate, it's my vocation.

rule.name: Collocation: in/on the outside
rule.message: The usual preposition for "outside" is "on" not "in". Revise: on the outside.
rule.example: There are white windows in the outside of the house.

rule.name: Collocation: in/on a island
rule.message: The usual preposition for "island" is "on" not "in". Revise: on \2 island.
rule.example: Our house is located in a small island surrounded by ices. There are no other houses around us.

rule.name: Collocation: Crazy on/with
rule.message: The usual preposition for "crazy" is "with" not "on". Revise: crazy with.
rule.example: What makes me crazy on this dwelling is that some time we are higher than the clouds.

rule.name: Collocation: Hide of/from
rule.message: The usual preposition for "\1" is "from" not "\2". Revise: \1 from.
rule.example: This is very useful to hide of prying tourists.

rule.name: Collocation: Concentrate with/on
rule.message: The usual preposition for "concentrate" is "on" not "\3". Revise: \2 on \4 \5.
rule.example: I know my life, it's not very interest because I am concentrated with my studies.

rule.name: Collocation: Difference about/between
rule.message: The usual preposition for "difference" is "between" not "about". Revise: difference between.
rule.example: There is not big difference about the week and the weekend to me.

rule.name: Collocation: Important with/to
rule.message: The usual preposition for "\1" is "to" not "with". Revise: \1 to \3.
rule.example: Family who is closest and important with you.

rule.name: Collocation: Consist to/of
rule.message: The usual preposition for "\1" is "of" not "to". Revise: \1 of.
rule.example: There is a program in medicine and this program consists to diagnostic people to know if their body works well.

rule.name: Collocation: in/on birthday
rule.message: The usual preposition for "birthdays" is "on". Revise: on \2 \3.
rule.example: My favorite thing is bag, I love my bag very much because it is a gift from my girl friend in my birthday, it is a red bag, I have kept it for 2 years and forever.

rule.name: Collocation: Participate to/in
rule.message: The usual preposition for "\1" is "in" not "to". Revise: \1 in.
rule.example: They participate to many activities, which contains organize laboratory experiments, supervise students research, conducting many lectures and of course, writing textbooks.

rule.name: Collocation: on/in a meeting
rule.message: The usual preposition for "\4 \5" is "in" not "on". Revise: \1 \2 in meeting.
rule.example: I was on a meeting.

rule.name: Collocation: at/in the morning
rule.message: The usual preposition for "\3" is "in" not "at". Revise: in the \3.
rule.example: I hardly ever drinks coffee at the morning because this make me crazy.

rule.name: Collocation: in/on a team
rule.message: The usual preposition for "team" is "on" not "in". Revise: on \5 \6.
rule.example: I’m the one Frank Catania need in his team.

rule.name: Collocation: addiction to/of
rule.message: The usual preposition for \1 is "to." Did you mean, \1 to \3?
rule.example: I would like to work with people who have an addiction of drugs.

rule.name: Collocation: on/in charge of
rule.message: The usual preposition for \5 is "in." Did you mean, \1 \2 \3 in charge of?

example.correction: is the person in charge of

rule.example: Julie is the person on charge to the security.

rule.name: Collocation: in/at a party
rule.message: Unless you mean "in a political party," the usual preposition for a party is "at." Did you mean, at a party?
rule.example: Later, I started working as a Research Assistant in university projects again, where I met her in a party.

rule.name: Collocation:
rule.message: The usual preposition for "\3...projects" is "on". Did you mean, \3 on \8 projects?

example.correction: working as a Research Assistant on university projects

rule.example: Later, I started working as a Research Assistant in university projects again.

rule.name: Collocation: suffer of/with/from
rule.message: The usual preposition for this expression is "from" or "with." Did you mean \1 from or \1 with?
rule.example: A clinical psychologist deals with people suffering of bipolar disorder.

rule.name: Collocation: talk down about/to
rule.message: The usual preposition for this expression is "to". Did you mean, \1 down to?
rule.example: Don't you ever talk down about my baby boy or Kristy.

rule.name: Collocation: in/on the foot
rule.message: The usual preposition for feet is "on". Did you mean, on \5 \6?
rule.example: He is wearing a crocs in my feet.

rule.name: Collocation: at/in the morning
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\3" is "in". Revise: in the \3.
rule.example: I like to do soccer on the evening.

rule.name: Collocation: at/over the weekend
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\3" is "over" or "during". Revise: over the \3 or during the \3.
rule.example: I like to do soccer on the weekend.

rule.name: Collocation: get a job in/with
rule.message: The usual preposition for "\1 \2 \3" is "with" for an organization. Revise: with \5 \6.
rule.example: The text is also a very important things for the people who want to get a job in the SPVM.

rule.name: Collocation: do/play game
rule.message: The usual collocation for an activity that does not end in "-ing" and is something you can win is "play" not "do" or "go." Revise: play \2.
rule.example: I like to do soccer on the weekend.
I like doing soccer on the weekend.

rule.name: Collocation: go/do art
rule.message: The usual collocation for an activity that does not end in "-ing" and is not something you can win is "do" not "go" or "play." Revise: do \2.
rule.example: My sister plays ballet at the community center.

rule.name: Collocation: do/go activity
rule.message: The usual collocation for an activity ending in "-ing" is "go" not "do" or "play." Revise: go \2.
rule.example: Do you do jogging?
He does jogging.
After the squad is done installing the gear.

rule.name: Collocation: damage of/to
rule.message: The usual collocation for word "damage" is "to" not "of." Revise: \1 to.
rule.example: It may cause damage of wildlife.

rule.name: Collocation: interest about/in
rule.message: The usual collocation for word "interest" is "in" not "about." Revise: \1 \2 in.
rule.example: They are more interest about the money, like how it's manage.

rule.name: Collocation: vulnerable from/to
rule.message: The usual collocation for word "vulnerable" is "to" not "from," as in "vulnerable to attack." Revise: vulnerable to.
rule.example: We do want to differ from other solutions where you must redirect all your domain names to a service provider, leaving your server vulnerable from direct attacks and having you hassle with domain records all the time.

rule.name: Collocation: imitation from/of
rule.message: The usual collocation for word "imitate" is "of" not "from," as in "imitate the style of someone." Revise: \1 \2 of \5 \6.

example.correction: imitate every habit and behavior of their parents

rule.example: Children imitate every habit and behavior from their parents.

rule.name: Collocation: offered in/at
rule.message: The usual preposition for "offered" and "\3" is "at" not "in." Revise: offered at \3.
rule.example: In addition, if people are in favor of women practicing combat sports, it would be beneficial to have combat sport sessions in schools as well as optional courses offered in universities.

rule.name: Collocation: perspectives about/on
rule.message: The usual preposition for "perspectives" is "on" not "about." Revise: perspectives on.
rule.example: They have different perspectives about the topic.

rule.name: Collocation: varieties in/of
rule.message: The usual preposition for "varieties" is "of" not "in." Revise: varieties of.
rule.example: They should increase varieties in food.

rule.name: Collocation: cover by/in
rule.message: The usual preposition for "cover" is "in" not "by." Revise: covered in \3 or covered with \3.
rule.example: The Mountains are covered by snow.

rule.name: Collocation: leave to/for
rule.message: The usual preposition for "leave" is "for" not "to". Revise: leaving for \3 \4.
rule.example: They are leaving to England soon.

rule.name: Collocation: do/have a meeting
rule.message: The usual verb for "a meeting" is "have" not "do." Revise: have a meeting.
rule.example: We decided to do a meeting the next day.
Tom does a meeting the next day.
We decided to did a meeting the next day.

rule.name: Collocation: growled to/at
rule.message: The usual preposition for "\1" is "at." Revise: \1 at \3.
rule.example: Dr. Dre growled to him about the snow.

rule.name: Collocation: to/on a trip
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\2" and "a trip" is "\2 on a trip". Did you mean \1 on a trip?
rule.example: Yes, I went to a trip.

rule.name: Collocation: in/on a trip
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\2 \3" is on \2 \3 or during \2 \3.
rule.example: It was is in his trip, that he met her.

rule.name: Collocation: think on/about
rule.message: The usual collocations for "\1" are \1 about or \1 of.
rule.example: I'm thinking in finish this text.

rule.name: Collocation: responsible of/for
rule.message: The usual collocations for "\1" is "\1 for". Did you mean \1 for or in charge of?
rule.example: I am responsable of marketing.

rule.name: Collocation:
rule.message: The usual collocations for "\1" is "\1 on," meaning act as an attendant to someone, or "\1 for" meaning to remain patiently inactive. Did you mean \1 for \3.
rule.example: I am waiting after her.

rule.name: Collocation: on/in a hospital bed
rule.message: The usual preposition with "\5" is "in". Did you mean in a hospital bed.
rule.example: The patient is on a hospital bed waiting for surgery.

rule.name: Collocation: live from/off
rule.message: The usual preposition with "\1" and "\7" is "off". Did you mean \1 off.
rule.example: He lives from his brother’s money.

rule.name: Collocation: anxious of/about
rule.message: The usual preposition with "\1" is "about". Did you mean anxious about.
rule.example: They are anxious for his health.
Parents are anxious for their children’s success.

rule.name: Collocation: be on/in shock
rule.message: The usual preposition with "\3" is "in". Did you mean \1 in shock.
rule.example: We were on shock when it happen..

rule.name: Collocation: far of/from
rule.message: The usual preposition for "far" is "from." Revise: far from.
rule.example: It is not very far of my job.

rule.name: Collocation: near from/to
rule.message: The usual preposition for "near" is "to." Revise: near to.
rule.example: It is not very near from my job.

rule.name: Collocation: blind for/from
rule.message: The usual preposition for "blind" is "from" when followed by the cause of the blindness. Revise: \1 from \3 \4.
rule.example: blind for the fury.

rule.name: Collocation: yell on/at
rule.message: The usual preposition for "yell" is "at." Revise: \1 at \3.
rule.example: Lily yelled on him.

rule.name: Collocation: takes into consideration (of)
rule.message: You have fused two expressions into one, "in consideration of" and "taking into consideration." Remove the word "of" from the end: \1 \2 \3.
rule.example: Tom takes into consideration of all the perspectives.

rule.name: Collocation: in/from the prespective
rule.message: The usual preposition for "perspective" is "from" not "in." from \2 \3 \4.
rule.example: In the psychological perspective.

rule.name: Collocation: sit on the court/bench
rule.message: The usual way to express a judge's association with a courtroom is with the phrase \1 on the bench.
rule.example: He is 67 year old and he sits on the court since 1998..

rule.name: Collocation: follow/take a course
rule.message: The usual verb for "courses" in a school is "take" or "attend" not "follow." Try it like this: take \2 courses.
rule.example: There is classes were students can follow their courses.

rule.name: Collocation: on/in the afternoon
rule.message: The usual preposition for "\3" is 'in' not "on". Try it like this: in \2 \3.
rule.example: The meeting is on the afternoon.

rule.name: Collocation: accuse for/of
rule.message: The usual preposition for accusations is "of" not "for." Try it like this: \1 the \3 of.
rule.example: She accused the man for stealing.

rule.name: Collocation: in/on a secret mission
rule.message: The usual preposition for "a secret mission" is "on" not "in". Try it like this: \1 on \3 \4 \5.
rule.example: Bond is in a secret mission.

rule.name: Collocation: laugh of/at
rule.message: The usual preposition for "laugh" is "at". Did you mean \1 at \3?
rule.example: I laughed of him.

rule.name: Collocation: bring at/to
rule.message: The usual preposition for "bring" is "to". Did you mean \1 \2 to?
rule.example: Bring Suzanne at the party.

rule.name: Collocation: on/in fact
rule.message: The usual preposition for "fact" is "in". Did you mean In fact?
rule.example: On fact, the people are fed up of so many elections.

rule.name: Collocation: bring to/put on the agenda
rule.message: The usual verb + preposition for "agenda" is "put on". Did you mean put on the agenda?
rule.example: We must bring to the agenda the people that are fed up of so many elections.

rule.name: Collocation: in front of
rule.message: The usual preposition for "in front" is "of". Did you mean in front of?
rule.example: In front to so many decisions, the people are fed up.

rule.name: Collocation: departure of/from
rule.message: The usual preposition for "departure" with a destination name is "from". Did you mean departure from?
rule.example: The stay is finally ended and they prepared their departure of New York.

rule.name: Collocation: live in/on planet
rule.message: The usual preposition for \4 is "on". Did you mean \1 on \4?
rule.example: Not all creatures that live in the planet Earth use oxygen.

rule.name: Collocation: countless of
rule.message: Do not use "of" after "\1". Did you mean \1 \3?
rule.example: There are countless of occurrences.

rule.name: Collocation: fed up of/with
rule.message: The usual preposition for "\1 \2" is "with". Did you mean \1 \2 with?
rule.example: The people are fed up of so many pointless elections.

rule.name: Collocation: enter in
rule.message: There isn't usually a preposition after "\1". Did you mean \1 \3 \4.
rule.example: While he was entering in the room, he felt an uncomfortable feeling on his spine.
The record is entered in a book.

rule.name: Collocation:
rule.message: There isn't usually a preposition before "\3". Did you mean \1 \3.
rule.example: Suzie went to home.
Carry went to home base.

rule.name: Collocation: came in/into
rule.message: The usual proposition after "\2" is "into" not "\3". The sentence "\1 \2 \3 \4 \5" is a colloquial expression for "\1 had an orgasm in the \5". Did you mean \1 \2 into \4 \5, meaning "\1 arrived"?
rule.example: Judy came in the house after greeting her elders.

rule.name: Collocation: arrive on/at the beach
rule.message: The usual proposition after "\1" is "at" not "\2". Did you mean \1 at.
rule.example: When John arrived on the beach, he went for a swim.

rule.name: Collocation: return at home
rule.message: You do not need a preposition between "\1" and "\3". Did you mean \1 \3.
rule.example: Return at home before midnight.

rule.name: Collocation: be in/under pressure
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\3" is "under" not "\2". Did you mean under pressure.
rule.example: Kelly is in pressure.

rule.name: Collocation: absorb at/in
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\1" is "in" not "\2". Did you mean \1 in.
rule.example: I am absorbed at this book.

rule.name: Collocation: accuse for/of
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\1" is "of" not "\2". Did you mean \1 of.
rule.example: He is accused for fraud.

rule.name: Collocation: ashamed from/of
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\1" is "of" not "\2". Did you mean \1 of.
rule.example: After flunking in the exam, she felt ashamed from it.

rule.name: Collocation: arrive at/in
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\1" is "in" not "\2". Use "in" for geographical regions and "at" for a specific point. For a town, province, state, country or continent, use "in". For a restaurant, business, park or car, use "at". Did you mean \1 in or '\1 at'.
rule.example: They will arrive at the city at 9:00 am.

rule.name: Collocation: angry with/about
rule.message: Use "angry with" for people. Use "angry about" for situations or weather. Did you mean \1 about the \4.
rule.example: Barbie is angry with the situation.

rule.name: Collocation: accustom with/to
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\1" is "to" not "\2". Did you mean \1 to.
rule.example: The mechanic is accustomed with handling those situations.

rule.name: Collocation: affraid from/of
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\1" is "of" not "\2". Did you mean \1 of.
rule.example: Rats are afraid from cats.

rule.name: Collocation: angry against/with
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\1" is "with" or "at" not "\2". Did you mean \1 with or \1 at.
rule.example: Birds fly when they are angry against pigs.

rule.name: Collocation: aim on/at
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\1" is "at" not "\2". Did you mean \1 at.
rule.example: This tool is aimed on regular users.

rule.name: Collocation: believe to/in
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\1" is "in" not "\2". Did you mean \1 in.
rule.example: 'cause I believe to fitness.

rule.name: Collocation: boast for/about/of
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\1" is "of" or "about" not "\2". Did you mean \1 of or \1 about.
rule.example: He boasted for his skills.

rule.name: Collocation: careful for/with
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\1" is "with" not "\2". Did you mean \1 with.
rule.example: Be careful for the camera.

rule.name: Collocation: travel with/by
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\1" is "by" not "\2". Did you mean \1 by \4.
rule.example: We are going to travel with a bus.

rule.name: Collocation: complain for/about
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\1" is "about" not "\2". Did you mean \1 about.
rule.example: The client complained for the service.

rule.name: Collocation: compose from/of
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\1" is "of" not "\2". Did you mean \1 of.
rule.example: It is composed from carbohydrates and proteins.

rule.name: Collocation: cure from/of
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\1" is "of" not "\2". Did you mean \1 of.
rule.example: This medicin will cure you from the disease.

rule.name: Collocation: deprive from/of
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\1" is "of" not "\2". Did you mean \1 of.
rule.example: This soil is deprived from nutrients.

rule.name: Collocation: die from/of
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\1" is "of" not "\2". Did you mean \1 of.
rule.example: The ferns are dying from too much watering.

rule.name: Collocation: disappoint from/with
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\1" is "with" or "in" or "by" or "at" or "about" not "\2". Did you mean \1 with or \1 in or \1 by or \1 at or \1 about.

example.correction: disappointed with|disappointed in|disappointed by|disappointed at|disappointed about

rule.example: She was disappointed from the surprise.

rule.name: Collocation: divide in/into
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\1" is "into" not "\4". Did you mean \1 \2 \3 into.
rule.example: Divide the pizza in four.

rule.name: Collocation: doubt for/in/about
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\1" is "in" or "about" not "\3". Did you mean \1 in or \1 about.
rule.example: I doubt for that.

rule.name: Collocation: dress with/in
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\2" is "in" not "\3". Did you mean \1 \2 in.
rule.example: Jane dresses with a coverall.

rule.name: Collocation: full with/of
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\1" is "of" not "\2". Did you mean \1 of.
rule.example: The washing machine is full with dishes.

rule.name: Collocation: rid from/of
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\1" is "of" not "\2". Did you mean \1 of.
rule.example: He got rid from the clutter.

rule.name: Collocation: glad with/about
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\1" is "about" not "\2". Did you mean \1 about.
rule.example: He's glad with it.

rule.name: Collocation: guard from/agains
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\1" is "against" not "\2". Did you mean \1 against.
rule.example: The dog guards from the thieves.

rule.name: Collocation: guilty for/of
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\1" is "of" not "\2". Did you mean \1 of.
rule.example: Mark is guilty for lazyness.
...the court enters a plea of not guilty for a defendant who refuses to enter a plea.

rule.name: Collocation: independently from/of
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\1" is "of" not "\2". Did you mean \1 of.
rule.example: Independently from our relationship, you are not the best, nor most the brightest.

rule.name: Collocation: insist on + gerund
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\1" is "on" not "\2". Did you mean \1 on ?
rule.example: She insisted to attend the conference.

rule.name: Collocation: interest for/in
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\1" is "in" not "\2". Did you mean \1 in.
rule.example: I have an interest for the sea.

rule.name: Collocation: jealous from/of
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\1" is "of" not "\2". Did you mean \1 of.
rule.example: Jane might be jealous from my car.

rule.name: Collocation: photo with/of + POSSESSIVE PRONOUN + NOUN
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\2" is "of" not "\3". Did you mean \2 of \4 \5.
rule.example: This is a photo with his cat.

rule.name: Collocation: in/at this moment
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\2 \3" is "at" not "\1". Did you mean At \2 \3.
rule.example: In this moment she woke up.

rule.name: Collocation: tired about/of
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\1" is "of" or "from" not "\2". Did you mean tired of or tired from.
rule.example: tired about.

rule.name: Collocation: advertisement of/for
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\1" is "for" not "\2". Did you mean advertisement for.
rule.example: Nice advertisement of your company.

rule.name: Collocation: stop him of/from
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\1 \2" is "from" not "of". Did you mean stop \2 from \4.
rule.example: This stops us of achieving victory.

rule.name: Collocation: in/on an album
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\3" is "on" not "in" when album refers to a collection of recorded music. If by "album" you mean a collection of photos, "in an album" is correct. Did you mean on \2 \3.
rule.example: Listen to that in the album.

rule.name: Collocation: cure against/for
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\1" is "for" not "against". Did you mean \1 for.
rule.example: Researcher have found the cure against that type of cancer.

rule.name: Collocation: to found/find a cure
rule.message: The verb "to found" means "to establish," but "to find" means "to discover." Did you mean to find \3 \4.
rule.example: It took a while to found a cure for malaria.

rule.name: Collocation: desire on/for
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\3" is "for" not "\4". Did you mean \3 for \5 \6?
rule.example: Even though some businessmen prefer unusual approaches to boost up their business identification, they get interested to identify the best approach to realize their desires on the business development.

rule.name: bring SOMEBODY in/to
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\1" is "to" not "\3" with. Did you mean \1 \2 to \4 \5.
rule.example: Friday came fast and the couple quitted their sweet house for took the bus who will brought them in the airport.

rule.name: curator on/of
rule.message: The usual collocation for "curator" is "of" not "\2". Did you mean \1 of \3 \4.
rule.example: The man to whom you were speaking to was the curator on the exposition.

rule.name: closer from/to
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\1" is "to" not "from". Did you mean simply \1 to or further from.
rule.example: I moved in July to be closer from school.

rule.name: article + possessive form
rule.message: A determiner cannot combine with a possessive pronoun. Did you mean simply \2 \3 or \1 \3.
rule.example: The mine car is on the maintenance services.

rule.name: I enrolled international school
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\2" is "in" (a school) or "for" (a course). Did you mean \1 \2 in or \1 \2 for.
rule.example: He enrolled at the college.

rule.name: steps to do/take
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\1" is "take". Did you mean \1 \2 take.
rule.example: There are some steps to do.

rule.name: going on vacation
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\3" is "on." Did you mean \1 on \3.
rule.example: She is going to vacation.

rule.name: I came by plane
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\2" is "on". Did you mean on \2.
rule.example: Check it in Wikipedia.

rule.name: Write on my page
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\1" is "on". Did you mean \1 on .
rule.example: That is written in page 21.
That is written in my own page.

example.correction: Write that on my own page

rule.example: Write that in my own page.

example.correction: Write that piece on my own page

rule.example: Write that piece in my own page.

rule.name: came to/by
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\2" is "by." Did you mean \1 \2 by \4.
rule.example: I came to plane.

rule.name: work (for) is
rule.message: You are missing the word 'for' between "\5" and '\6'. Did you mean \1 \2 that \4 \5 for \6.

example.correction: The company that I work for is

rule.example: The company that I work is Cosme Inc...

rule.name: waiting (for) a patient
rule.message: You are missing the word 'for' between "\1" and "\1 \2". Did you mean \1 for \2 \3.
rule.example: Anne is waiting her patient.

rule.name: travel (for) X days
rule.message: You are missing the word "for" between "\2" and "\3". Did you mean \1 traveled for \3 \4.
rule.example: I traveled four days.

rule.name: Respectful against/toward
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\1" is 'toward' but never 'toward'. Did you mean \1 toward.
rule.example: Respectful against.

rule.name: Disappointed with, at, or by
rule.message: The usual collocation for 'disappointed' is 'with', 'at', of 'by, but never "of". Did you mean \1 with.
rule.example: We could be disappointed of this announcement.
While we were returning in the office, I have been arrested for speeding.
rule.message: "\1"的常用搭配是"to" 而不是"\2"。 你是说 \1 to 吗?

rule.example: While we were returning in Montreal, I have been arrested for speeding.
rule.message: "\1"的常用搭配是"to" 而不是"\2"。 你是说 \1 to 吗?
In English, the normal collocation for "party" is "have" or "throw". Revise your sentence: to throw a party or to have a party.

example.correction: to throw a party|to have a party

rule.example: A new roommate has moved in, so we decided to do a party with all of us..

rule.message: In English, the normal collocation for "party" is "have" or "throw". Revise your sentence: \1 throwing a party or \1 partying.
rule.example: I like making a party.

rule.message: The usual collocation for "in charge" is "of" not "for". Did you mean in charge of.
rule.example: Who is in charge for this shop?

rule.message: The usual collocation for "\2" is "with" not "\3". Did you mean \2 with.
rule.example: charge for.
Brevity is essential because you will be charged for every word.

rule.message: The usual preposition for "the weekend" is "on." Revise: on the weekend for American English, or at the weekend for British English.
rule.example: During the week, I go to school and I work in a pet shop during the weekend.

rule.message: The usual preposition for "the weekend" is "on." Revise: on the weekend for American English, or at the weekend for British English.
rule.example: During the week, I go to school and I work in a pet shop during the week end.

rule.message: The usual preposition for "weekends" is "on." Revise: on weekends for American English, or at the weekend for British English.
rule.example: I only speak English on weekends because during weekends I work and some clients that only speak in English.
During the week, I go to school and I work in a pet shop during the weekends.

rule.message: The usual preposition for "a \2" with a named destination is "to". Did you mean a trip to?
rule.example: John and Jenny week decided to go on a trip in New York.

rule.message: The usual preposition for "a \2" with a named destination is "to". Did you mean a trip to?
rule.example: John and Jenny week decided to go on a trip in York.

rule.message: The usual preposition for "a \2" with a named destination is "to". Did you mean a trip to?
rule.example: John and Jenny week decided to go on a trip in New-York.

rule.message: The usual verb for "\3" is "watch". Did you mean watch \3?
rule.example: During my free time, I like listen to movies in cinema with my boyfriend and my friends.

rule.message: The usual verb for "\3" is "watch". Did you mean watch a \4?
rule.example: During my free time, I like listen to movie with my boyfriend and my friends.
During my free time, I like listen to a movie in cinema with my boyfriend and my friends.
During the week, I listen series or action movie in English because I want to improve myself with my sister.

rule.message: The usual verb for "\3" is "watch". Did you mean watch an \4 \5?
rule.example: During the week, I listen to action movie in English because I want to improve myself with my sister.

rule.message: The usual preposition for team membership is "on" not "in". Try it like this: on \2 \3's \6.
rule.example: in the men's team.

rule.message: The usual preposition for team membership is "on" not "in". Try it like this: on \2 \3's \6 \7.
rule.example: in the men's basketball team.

rule.message: The usual preposition for team membership is "on" not "in". Try it like this: on \2 \3's \6 \7 \8.

rule.example: in the men's basket ball team.

rule.message: The usual preposition for "\3 \4" is "in" not "to." Try it like this: \1 in the \4.
rule.example: Their arrival to the city will be at one o'clock.

rule.message: The usual preposition for "\3 \4" is "at" not "to." Try it like this: \1 at the \4.
rule.example: At that time, their arrival to the house was a surprise.

rule.message: The usual preposition for mode of transportation is "by" not "in". Try it like this: \1 by \3.
rule.example: She comes in car.

rule.message: The usual preposition for mode of transportation is "by" not "in". Try it like this: \1 \2 \3 by \5.
rule.example: She comes to work in car.

rule.message: Use "good at" to mean "skilled" with school subjects. Try this: \1 at \3 \4.
rule.example: I'm good in world geography.

rule.message: Use "good at" to mean "skilled" with school subjects. Try this: \1 at \3 \4.

rule.message: Use "good at" to mean "skilled" with school subjects. Try this: \1 at \3 \4.

rule.message: Use "good at" to mean "skilled" with school subjects. Try this: \1 at \3 \4.

rule.message: Use "good at" to mean "skilled" with school subjects. Try this: \1 at \3 \4.

rule.message: Use "good at" to mean "skilled" with school subjects. Try this: \1 at \3 \4.

rule.message: Use "good at" to mean "skilled" with school subjects. Try this: \1 at \3.
rule.example: I'm good in math. I was good in running errands.

rule.name: Collocation: good in/at
rule.message: The usual preposition for this expression is "at". Did you mean, \1 at \3?

rule.name: make since (sense)
rule.example: Something like 90 most likely never makes since.
There have been three made since the launch.
Many changes have been made since my previous visit.
rule.message: 你是想说 sense 吗?

rule.name: all and all (all in all)
rule.example: One for all and all for one!
All and all it’s just another brick in the… toilet?
rule.message: 这个短语不规范。你是说 all in all (毕竟, 尽管如此)?

rulegroup.name: all of the sudden (all of a sudden)

rule.example: Why would a man all of the sudden send flowers?
Why would anyone all of a sudden send flowers?
rule.message: 这个短语不规范。你是说 all of a sudden 吗?

rule.example: Why would a man all the sudden send flowers?
Why would anyone all of a sudden send flowers?
rule.message: 这个短语不规范。你是说 all of a sudden 吗?

rule.name: along the same vein (along the same line, in the same vein)

example.correction: in the same vein|along the same line

rule.example: I've been working along the same vein.
rule.message: 这个短语不规范。使用 in the same vein or along the same line .

rule.name: Misused phrase: 'ever so often (every so often)'
rule.example: Ever so often, we put down the books, and go sailing!
rule.message: 在写作中这个短语是不规范的。你是想说 every \2 \3 吗?

rule.name: early adapter (early adopter)
rule.example: DualCore PC is available for purchase for selected companies in the early adapter program.
rule.message: 你是想说 early adopter (先行者)?

rule.name: far be it for me (far be it from me)
rule.example: Far be it for me to say that you can’t.
rule.message: 你是想说 far be it from me (绝不会)?

rule.name: money is no option (money is no object)
rule.example: Money is no option when are you rich.
rule.message: 你是说 money is no object (钱不是问题)?

rule.name: nip it in the butt (nip it in the bud)
rule.example: We'd like to nip it in the butt right here.
rule.message: 你是想说 nip it in the bud (消灭在萌芽期)吗?

rule.name: now and days (nowadays)
rule.example: Money is becoming pretty tight now and days.
rule.message: 你是想说 nowadays 吗?

rule.name: the proof is in the pudding (the proof of the pudding is in the eating)

example.correction: The proof of the pudding is in the eating
example.marker: The Proof Is In The Pudding

rule.example: The proof of the pudding is in the eating.
rule.message: 如果你不想从你的布丁里找东西，你是在说 the proof of the pudding is in the eating .

rule.name: qui bono (cui bono)
rule.example: Let me ask: qui bono?
rule.message: 非标准拉丁语。 你是想说 cui bono (是谁得益)吗？

rule.name: whip cream (whipped cream)
rule.example: Whip cream until it becomes whip cream.
rule.message: 你是想说 whipped cream 吗?

rule.name: in/with regards to/of (regarding, with regard to)
rule.example: Please be aware of the following changes in regards to this program.
But, they would assist in some way with regards to the criminal prosecution.
With regards to America, we must not forget that the…
The hotel is satisfactory in regards of quality and price.
Please be aware of the following changes in this program.
But, they would assist in some way with regard to the criminal prosecution.
But, they would assist in some way in regard to the criminal prosecution.
But, they would assist in some way regarding the criminal prosecution.
I hope this letter finds you well. Love Mike. P.S. With regards to Susan.
rule.message: 用 in regard to , with regard to , or more simply regarding .

rule.name: very known (very well-known, well-known)
rule.example: He is a very known actor.
rule.message: 不正确的短语。用 very well-known or well-known 。

rule.example: I've got a new car.
I've a new car.
rule.message: 这是一个不规范的缩写。用 \1 have \4 or \1've got \4 to express possession.

rule.example: I've got three new cars.
I've three new cars.
rule.message: 这是一个不规范的缩写。用 \1 have \4 or \1've got \4 to express possession.
Wrong phrase. Use \1\2\3 or \1 \4\5\6.
rule.example: It's 7:00 o'clock.

rule.message: Wrong phrase; 'o'clock is used only at the full hour. Use simply \1\2\3 instead.
rule.example: It's 7 o'clock.
It's 7:45 o'clock.

rule.name: 5-farads/5-farad
rule.example: Use a 6-microfarads capacitor.
Use a 6-microfarad capacitor.
A 10-milliohms resistor is necessary.
Use a 10-metres rope.
The 4.6-centigrammes difference is not a problem.
Also find typgoraphic errors: a 5.7.8-femtogrammes difference is not important.
rule.message: 单词 ''是个形容词(国际计量单位),但是拼写是错的。 不要使用形容词的复数。请参阅"国际单位系统（SI）"中的第5.3.3节。

rule.example: As the wife of a former alumnus of UCLA, I am appalled at recent events that have occurred and seemingly encouraged by the administration.
rule.message: 这个短语是多余的。考虑写成 an .

rule.example: The former alumnus adviser of Alpha Lambda Chapter was elected as congressman-at- large in Ohio.
rule.message: 这个短语是多余的。考虑写成 an .

rule.example: A sworn affidavit is a written statement made by someone under oath to tell the truth about something.
rule.message: 这个短语是多余的。考虑写成 an

rule.example: His sworn affidavit was deposited in the post office mailbox.
rule.message: 这个短语是多余的。考虑写成 an

rule.name: directly antithetical (antithetical)
rule.message: This phrase verges on redundancy. Consider writing .
rule.example: The two events this week were directly antithetical to the University's values for these reasons.
The two events this week were antithetical to the University's values for these reasons.

rule.name: approximately about
rule.message: This phrase is redundant. Consider using .
rule.example: Americans feel full of energy and healthy approximately about 19 days per month.
Americans feel full of energy and healthy approximately 19 days per month.
In reasoning about a complex system, humans reason approximately about its behavior.
Hippos associate together in groups.
rule.message: 这个短语是多余的。考虑写成 .

rule.example: Poets and choregi having been associated together in pairs, there still remained the selection and appointment of the actors.
rule.message: 这个短语是多余的。考虑写成 .

rule.name: sufficient enough -> sufficient
rule.example: The money is sufficient enough to buy the pullover.
rule.message: 'Sufficient enough'是多余的。考虑只用 sufficient .

rule.name: of any of -> of
rule.example: He was the worst of any of the dancers
rule.message: 考虑只用 of 。

rule.name: Possibly needless 'that'
rule.message: "\2" may be unnecessary here.
rule.example: I am pretty sure that this is right.
I am pretty sure this is right.
It has grown way beyond that.

rule.name: send an email to (email)
rule.example: He was going to email her.
He was going to send an email to her.
rule.message: 考虑用单个动词 email .

rule.name: sent an email to (email)
rule.example: He sent an email to her.
He emailed her.
rule.message: 考虑用单个动词emailed .

rule.name: the world around it (the world)
rule.example: He didn't like the world around him.
He didn't like the world.
rule.message: 考虑用 the world .

rule.name: because of the fact that (because)
rule.example: Its crystals are usually hexagonal in shape, with flakiness and plating, usually because of the fact that it replaced a mineral.
rule.message: 这个短语是多余的。考虑写成 because .

rule.name: Wordiness: in a ... manner
rule.example: He came in a hasty manner.
He came hastily.
rule.message: 考虑将"1 \ 2 \ 3 \ 4"替换为副词"3"。例如，把"in a hasty manner"换成"hastily".

rule.example: ATM Machine Comparison Guide
rule.message: 这个词是多余的('M'代表'machine')。考虑用 \1 .

rule.example: In the Netherlands, criminals are stealing money from ATM machines by blowing them up.
ATMs are quite common in the Netherlands,
rule.message: 这个词是多余的('M'代表'machine')。考虑用 \1 .

rule.name: absolutely essential/necessary (essential/necessary)
rule.example: This is absolutely essential.
This was essential.
rule.message: 考虑用 \2 .

rule.name: actual experience/facts (experience/facts)
rule.example: This talk is based on actual experience gained during recovery operations following a fire at the Washington National Records.
This play is based on facts.
rule.message: 考虑用 \2 .

rule.name: advance planning/preview/reservations/warning (planning/preview/reservations/warning)
rule.example: Advance planning is one strategy couples can use to establish legal rights.
rule.message: 这个词是多余的。考虑用 \2 .

rule.name: add an additional (add)
rule.message: This phrase might be redundant. Consider using .
rule.example: How to Add an Additional Page to a Full Flash Site
It's 7 o'clock a.m.
It's 7 o'clock AM.
It's 7,30 p.m.
The asteroid will arrive first-class at 10.45 a.m.
rule.message: 你是说 \1:\3 吗?

rule.example: It's 5 AM in the morning.
He doesn't know where I am in the morning.
rule.message: 考虑用 \1 .

rule.example: It's 5 A.M. in the morning.
It's 5 A.M.
rule.message: 考虑用 \1 .

rule.example: It's 5 PM in the evening.
rule.message: 考虑用 \1 .

rule.example: It's 1 PM at night.
It's 5 PM.
rule.message: 考虑用 \1 .

rule.example: It's 5 P.M. in the afternoon.
It's 5 P.M.
rule.message: 考虑用 \1 .

rule.example: It's 1 P.M. at night.
It's 5 P.M.
rule.message: 考虑用 \1 .

rule.name: and also (and/also)
rule.example: Typical English Food and also Welsh and Scottish too
Typical English Food, and Welsh and Scottish too
rule.message: 考虑只用 and 或also .

rule.name: and etc. (etc.)
rule.example: E-Commerce and etc.

rule.name: annual anniversary (anniversary)
rule.example: First Annual Anniversary Contest
rule.message: 考虑用 \2 instead.

rule.name: added bonus (bonus)
rule.example: Added bonus: booting from cdrom.
Bonus: booting from CD-ROM.
rule.message: 这个短语有可能是多余的。考虑用 \2 .

rule.name: adequate enough (adequate)
rule.example: The Allen test is not adequate enough for the screening of hand circulation.
rule.message: 这个短语有可能是多余的。考虑用 \1 .

rule.name: are able to (can)
rule.example: Yes, there are some species of frogs that can throw up their entire stomach and wipe it off with their legs.
Yes, there are some species of frogs that are able to throw up their entire stomach and wipe it off with their legs.
rule.message: 这个表达是冗长的。考虑用 can .

rule.name: ask the question (ask)
rule.example: He asked the question.
He asked the question whether it's OK to add some rules to LanguageTool.
rule.message: 考虑用 \1替换.

rule.name: as of yet (yet)
rule.example: The report remains unfinished as of yet.
rule.message: 考虑用 yet或as yet .

rule.name: armed gunman (gunman)
rule.example: Armed gunmen entered the room to kill Bill.
Gunmen are very dangerous in this city.
rule.message: 这个词语也许是多余的。考虑用 \2 .

rule.name: autobiography of a life (autobiography)
rule.example: In this autobiography of a life of courage and love, we get to share in the compelling story of a family’s struggles.
In this story of a life of courage and love, we get to share in the compelling story of a family’s struggles
rule.message: 考虑用 \1 or story \2 \3 \4 instead.

rule.name: basic fundamentals/necessities (fundamentals/necessities)
rule.example: Visual Basic Fundamentals
Let’s get back to the basic fundamentals!
rule.message: 考虑用 \2 .

rule.name: bald-headed (bald)
rule.example: He is bald-headed.
Kojak was bald.
rule.message: 考虑用 bald .

rule.name: balsa wood (balsa)
rule.example: It's made of balsa wood.
This table is made of balsa.
rule.message: 考虑用 \1 .

rule.name: bare naked (naked)
rule.example: The old man ran bare naked through the streets.
rule.message: 考虑用 \2 .

rule.name: best ever (best)
rule.example: Top ten best ever beer names.
Top ten best beer names.
rule.message: 这个词语也许是多余的。考虑用 \1 .

rule.name: temporary bivouac (bivouac)
rule.message: This phrase may be redundant. Consider writing .
rule.example: In temporary bivouac areas (1 to 3 days), the straddle trench latrine is used unless more permanent facilities are provided for the unit.

rule.name: bivouac camp (bivouac)
rule.message: This phrase is redundant. Consider writing .
rule.example: A rock climber leaves a hanging bivouac camp on an Arctic cliff
A rock climber leaves a hanging bivouac on an Arctic cliff

rule.name: Big in size, yellow in color, etc.
rule.example: He's absorbed in thought.
The man is big in size.
His speech was briefest in duration.
My car is redder in color.
Her friends were few in number.
I really need to get back in shape.
rule.message: 一个更简洁的短语不但不会使意思有所变动，还会更有力。

rule.name: bitter in taste (bitter)
rule.example: This beer is bitter in taste.
rule.message: 考虑用 \1 .

rule.name: blend together (blend)
rule.example: Their voices blend together in lovely harmony.
Their voices blend in lovely harmony.
rule.message: 成分冗余，建议使用 \1 .

rule.name: boat marina (marina)
rule.example: Taupo Boat Marina
rule.message: 建议使用 \2 .

rule.name: brief in duration (brief)
rule.example: However, most wilderness programs are brief in duration.
rule.message: 建议使用 \1 .

rule.name: brief moment/summary (moment/summary)
rule.example: A Brief Moment of Compassion
A Moment of Compassion
rule.message: 建议使用 \2 .

rule.name: biography of her life (biography)
rule.example: In this biography of her life, we get to share in the compelling story of a family’s struggles.
In this story of a life of courage and love, we get to share in the compelling story of a family’s struggles
rule.message: 建议使用 \1 或 story \2 \3 \4 .

rule.name: bouquet of flowers (bouquet)
rule.example: What a beautiful bouquet of flowers!
rule.message: 成分冗余，建议使用 \1 .

rule.name: but nevertheless/however (but)
rule.example: I should not have, but nevertheless I did.
rule.message: 建议使用 \1 .

rule.name: CD disc (CD)
rule.example: I ordered a CD disk with their software.
I ordered a CD with their software.
I ordered a DVD with their software.
rule.message: 建议使用 \1 .

rule.name: CDROM (CD-ROM)
rule.example: I ordered a Cdrom with their software.
I ordered a CD-ROM with their software.
rule.message: 建议使用 CD-ROM .

rule.example: I've lived in Barcelona for tree years.
rule.message: 你是说 three 吗?

rule.name: accused of a charge (charged with)
rule.example: The Magistrate's Court in Kuala Lumpur today decided that a former model accused of a charge of public indecency is fit to stand trial.
rule.message: 冗余，建议使用: charged with instead.

rule.name: circumstances surrounding (circumstances of)
rule.message: This phrase is redundant. Consider writing of.
rule.example: Based upon this discussion, the OIG expanded the scope of its investigation to analyze the circumstances surrounding the settlement rejected by Judge Rakoff.
The majority of Jannali's enterprises are located within close proximity to the suburb's railway station.
rule.message: 这个句子是冗长的。考虑写成: close to .

rule.example: Their manifesto yesterday received the same close scrutiny as the other two big parties — and it was an uncomfortable experience.
rule.message: 这个句子是冗长的。考虑写成: close to .

rule.name: comfortable with doing (comfortable doing)
rule.example: I am not comfortable with dancing with strangers.
rule.message: 建议使用 \1 \3 .

rule.name: common bond (bond)
rule.example: They formed a common bond against the British
rule.message: 建议使用 \2 .

rule.name: commute back and forth (commute)
rule.example: She will commute back and forth between New Haven and her home in Southern California before relocating to the Elm City this summer.
She will commute between New Haven and her home in Southern California before relocating to the Elm City this summer
rule.message: 建议使用 \1 .

rule.name: consensus of opinion (consensus)
rule.example: Wim Duisenberg, the ECB's Dutch president, is seen as a leader who seeks to fashion a consensus of opinion on the council rather than imposing his own views, as some chairmen of the US Federal Reserve have done.
rule.message: 建议使用 \1 .

rule.name: continue to remain (remain)
rule.message: Consider using remain.
rule.example: We continued to remain optimistic.
We remain optimistic.

rule.name: descend down (descend)
rule.example: The Pentagon aides and journalists descend down the back stairs of the plane as is customary while Rumsfeld comes down the main stairs to meet his welcome party.
rule.message: 成分冗长。建议使用 \1 .

rule.name: during the course of (during)
rule.example: He never smiled during the course of the trial.
rule.message: 建议使用 \1 .

rule.name: each and every one (each one)
rule.example: God bless each and every one of you!
rule.message: 建议使用 \1 \4 .

rulegroup.name: Suggest shorter ways to negate words (not common vs uncommon)

rule.example: The list is not complete.
The list is incomplete.
rule.message: 考虑用 in\3 .

rule.example: The rock is not steady.
The rock is unsteady.
rule.message: 考虑用 in\3 .

rule.example: The paragraph is not perfect.
The paragraph is imperfect.
rule.message: 考虑用 in\3 .

rule.example: The student was not rational.
The student was irrational.
rule.message: 考虑用 in\3 .

rule.example: The car was not fast enough to win the race.
The car was too slow to win the race.
rule.message: 考虑用 in\3 .

rule.example: The car was not large enough for the tall man.
The car was too small for the large man.
rule.message: 考虑用 in\3 .

rule.example: The car was not small enough to fit through the tunnel.
The car was too large to fit through the tunnel.
rule.message: 考虑用 in\3 .

rule.name: all of the (all the)
rule.example: She is going to all of the parks.
She is going some or all of the parks.
rule.message: 建议使用 all the .

rule.name: self-admitted (admitted)
rule.example: Springfield police arrest 'very dangerous, self-admitted gang member.'
rule.message: 这个词语是冗余的。建议使用 admitted .

rule.name: some of the (some)
rule.example: Some of the parks are in the area.
She is going to buy some parks.
She is going all or some of the parks.
He is putting out some of the most inspired music of his life.
They want to answer some of the universe’s deepest questions.
rule.message: 建议使用 some .

rule.name: try and (try to)
rule.example: She is going to try and go to the store.
rule.message: "Try and"在口语演讲中很常见，但"try to "更适合用在写作中。

rule.name: so as to (to)
rule.example: The band practiced so as to increase their chances of success.
rule.message: 建议使用 to

rule.name: on a few occasions (occasionally)
rule.example: The man drank on a few occasions.
rule.message: 建议使用 occasionally

rule.name: there are also other (also)
rule.example: However, there are also other marbles in the jar.
There are other marbles in the jar.
rule.message: 建议使用 there are other 或 there are also

rule.name: a large number of (many)
rule.example: A large number of people were in the parade.
rule.message: 指定一个数字、删除短语或只用 many or numerous

rule.name: a small number of (a few)
rule.example: A small number of people were in the store.
Few people were in the store.
rule.message: 指定一个数字、删除短语或只用 a few , or use some

rule.name: subsequent to (after)
rule.example: The roads needed repairs subsequent to the storm.
rule.message: 建议使用 after

rule.name: hollow tube (tube)
rule.example: We fixed the hollow tube.
rule.message: 建议使用 tube

rule.name: exact replica (replica)
rule.example: We created an exact replica of the building.
We created a replica of the building.
rule.message: 建议使用 replica

rule.name: with the exception of (except)
rule.example: With the exception of Bob, all of the children went running.
rule.message: 建议使用 except or except for

rule.name: every now and then (now and then)
rule.example: Every now and then the faucet drips.

rule.name: established fact (fact)
rule.message: Consider using .
rule.example: This is an established fact.
This is the exact same situation.
This is the same situation.
rule.message: 考虑用 \2 .

rule.example: This shoe is exactly the same.
This shoe is the same.
rule.message: 考虑用 \2 .

rule.example: It is warm during the summertime.
rule.message: 考虑用 summer .

rule.example: It is warm during the summer time.
It is warm during the summer.
For information about British Summer Time (BST), refer to https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/British_Summer_Time.
For information about Western European Summer Time, refer to https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Western_European_Summer_Time.
rule.message: 考虑用 summer .

rule.name: fall season (fall)
rule.example: The leaves turn red and gold in the fall season.
rule.message: 建议使用 \2 .

rule.name: famous celebrity (celebrity)
rule.example: I'm told that he's a famous celebrity now.
rule.message: 建议使用 \2 .

rule.name: salsa sauce (salsa)
rule.example: I enjoy eating salsa sauce.
rule.message: 建议使用 \1 .

rule.name: general public (public)
rule.example: We should show this to the general public.
rule.message: 建议使用 \2 .

rule.name: new innovation (innovation)
rule.example: He was a new recruit.
rule.message: 建议使用 \2 .

rule.name: originally discovered (discovered)
rule.example: He originally discovered gold.
rule.message: 建议使用 \2 .

rule.name: former graduate (graduate)
rule.example: I am a former graduate of the school.
rule.message: 建议使用 \2 .

rule.example: I enjoy over exaggerating.
rule.message: 考虑用 \2 .

rule.example: I enjoy over-exaggerating.
rule.message: 考虑用 \2 .

rule.name: originally born in (born in)
rule.example: I was originally born in Texas.
rule.message: 建议使用 \2 \3 .

rule.name: return back (return)
rule.example: We returned back home.
rule.message: 建议使用 \1 .

rule.name: repeat again (repeat)
rule.example: We made the song repeat again.
rule.message: 建议使用 \1 .

rule.name: might perhaps (might)
rule.example: We might possibly go fishing.

rulegroup.name: disagree with the fact that (disagree that)

rule.example: I agree with the fact that the sky is blue.
rule.message: 考虑用 \1 that .

rule.example: We did not disagree with the fact that the sky is blue.
rule.message: 考虑用 \1 that .

rule.name: will in the future (will)
rule.example: I will in the future work hard.
rule.message: 建议使用 will .

rule.name: work colleague (colleague)
rule.example: I will talk to a work colleague.
rule.message: 建议使用 \2 .

rule.name: numerous different (numerous)
rule.example: I will read many different books
I will read many books.
rule.message: 建议使用 \1 .

rule.name: whole lot (lot)
rule.example: I will read a whole lot of books
I will read a lot of books.
rule.message: 建议使用 \2 .

rule.name: fellow classmates/co-workers/comrades (classmates/co-workers/comrades)
rule.example: I would enjoy a reunion with my fellow classmates.
rule.message: 建议使用 \2 .

rule.name: few in number (few)
rule.example: They were few in number, but mighty.
rule.message: 建议使用 \1 .

rule.name: first time ever (first time)
rule.example: We have a pig in space for the first time ever.
rule.message: 建议使用 \1 \2 .

rule.name: foreign import (import)
rule.example: The rise in foreign imports, the argument goes, is forcing some Americans to accept lower pay to remain competitive with, say, Mexican and Chinese workers.
rule.message: 成分冗余。建议使用 \2 .

rule.name: forever and ever (forever)
rule.example: It is you and me, forever and ever.
rule.message: 建议使用 \1 .

rule.name: from whence (whence)
rule.example: Go back from whence you came.
Go back whence you came!
rule.message: 建议使用 \2 .

rule.name: honest truth (truth)
rule.example: That is the honest truth of the matter.
That is the truth of the matter.
rule.message: 建议使用 \2 .

rule.name: in order to (to)
rule.example: We opened the door in order to enter.
We opened the door to enter.
rule.message: 成分冗余。建议使用 \3 .

rule.name: introduce for the first time (introduce)
rule.example: We were introduced for the first time a week ago.
rule.message: 建议使用 \1 .

rule.name: main focus (focus)
rule.example: Redundancies are the main focus of my essay.
rule.message: 建议使用 \2 .

rule.name: major breakthrough (breakthrough)
rule.example: It was a major breakthrough in genetic research.
rule.message: 建议使用 \2 .

rule.name: can/could/may/might possibly (can/could/may/might)
rule.example: That may possibly be the greatest blunder of all.
rule.message: 建议使用 \1 .

rule.name: mental telepathy (telepathy)
rule.example: Do cats really use mental telepathy?
rule.message: 建议使用 \2 .

rule.name: mutually dependent on each other (mutually dependent)
rule.example: Well, they're mutually dependent on each other.
rule.message: 建议使用 \1 \2 .

rule.name: never at any time (never)
rule.example: I was never at any time with that woman.
rule.message: 建议使用 \1 .

rule.name: the noun around it (surrounding noun)
rule.example: He didn't like the protesters around him.
rule.message: 建议使用 the surrounding \2 .

rule.name: now currently (now)
rule.example: She is now currently the ambassador.
rule.message: 建议使用 \1 .

rule.name: one and the same (the same)
rule.example: Santa Claus and Saint Nick are one and the same person.
rule.message: 建议使用 \3 \4 .

rule.name: or alternatively (or)
rule.example: We can either do this now or alternatively leave it for tomorrow.
rule.message: 建议使用 \1 .

rule.name: passing fad (fad)
rule.example: Computers are just a passing fad.
rule.message: 建议使用 \2 .

rule.name: past experience/memory (experience/memory)
rule.example: We know from past experience that weakness breeds contempt.
rule.message: 建议使用 \2 .

rule.name: period of time (period)
rule.example: Horses were absent throughout that period of time.
rule.message: 建议使用 \1 .

rule.name: personal charm/belongings/opinion/friendship (charm/belongings/opinion/belongings)
rule.example: In my personal opinion, canaries are quite tasty.
rule.message: 建议使用 \2 .

rule.name: point being is that (point is that/point being that)
rule.example: The point being is that Russia and Japan weren't even at war.
The point is that Russia and Japan weren't even at war

rule.name: reason why (reason)
rule.example: The reason why I did that is simple.
The reason I did that is simple.
rule.message: 建议使用 \2 .

rule.name: so therefore (therefore)
rule.example: I am me, the only me, so therefore I am unique, which in turn makes me special :)
rule.message: 建议使用 \1 或 \2 .

rule.name: therapeutic treatment (treatment)
rule.example: My swelled knee required special therapeutic treatment.
rule.message: 建议使用 \2 .

rule.name: rustic country (rustic)
rule.example: She loved her rustic country kitchen.
rule.message: 建议使用 \1 .

rule.name: safe haven (haven)
rule.example: They ran for the forest, searching for a safe haven.
rule.message: 建议使用 \2 .

rule.name: usual custom (custom)
rule.example: Eggnog on Christmas is our usual custom.
rule.message: 建议使用 \2 .

rule.name: very unique (unique)
rule.example: Walk until you see the very unique building on your right.
Walk until you see a unique building on your right.
rule.message: 建议使用 \2 .

example.correction: Whether|Whether or not|As to whether|The question whether|As to whether or not

rule.example: The question as to whether or not it is difficult is not our concern.
rule.message: 用词累赘:考虑把句子变短。

rule.example: The question as to whether it is difficult is not our concern.
rule.message: 用词累赘:考虑把句子变短。

rule.example: The question of whether it is difficult is not our concern.
rule.message: 用词累赘:考虑把句子变短。

rule.example: We are not concern as to whether or not it is difficult.
rule.message: 用词累赘:考虑把句子变短。

rule.example: The question whether it is difficult is not our concern.
rule.message: 用词累赘:考虑把句子变短。

rule.example: As to whether it is difficult, we are not concern.
Whether it is difficult is not our concern.
We are not concern whether it is difficult.
rule.message: 用词累赘:考虑把句子变短。

rule.example: What the government decides to do depends on whether or not the bill passes.
rule.message: 用词累赘:考虑把句子变短。

rule.name: female actor (actress)
rule.example: She was the first female actor.
rule.message: 考虑使用 actress .

rule.name: female waiter (waitress)
rule.example: She was the first female waiter.
rule.message: 考虑使用 waitress .

rule.name: first woman president (female president)
rule.example: She was the first woman president.
rule.message: 建议使用 female .

rule.name: first man president (male president)
rule.example: He was the first man employee of the company.
He was the first man Sarah ever kissed.
rule.message: 建议使用 male .

rule.name: little bit
rule.example: He was a little bit late.
rule.message: 成分冗余，建议使用 little 或 bit

rule.name: free gift
rule.message: This phrase is redundant. Consider using .
rule.example: Receive a free gift with every purchase.
Compare the best phone deals with free gifts, from tablets and TVs to …
Free gifts for you to keep!
Receive a gift with every purchase.

rule.name: be bigger than me (I)
rule.example: She is wiser than me!
She is prettier than her younger sister.
rule.message: 在正式/书面英语中，主语代词是比较推荐的。

rule.name: most (almost) every
rule.example: Most everyone saw him.
They are most everywhere.
rule.message: '\1 \2'表达太口语化。在正式/书面英语中应该要避免。应使用 almost \2 !

rule.name: where/when
rule.example: There are times where you need to measure high current devices.
Do you remember the happy days where we were together
rule.message: 最好用'\1'和时间代词'when'连用: \1 when . (Alternatively, use 'in/on which')

rule.name: Profanity
rule.example: Piss off!
Go away!
Carleton S. Coon was an American anthropologist (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carleton_S._Coon).
rule.message: 这个词被认为是无礼的。

rule.name: 'Needs fixed' type construction
rule.example: My car needs fixed.
A set of needs described as essential
rule.message: "\1 \2"只有在特定的方言中才能被接受。为了能被更广泛地接受，试试用 or to be \2 .

rule.name: an invite (invitation)
rule.example: Is that an invite...?
rule.message: 仅用在非正式的登记中。在其他登记中,应该用invitation 。

rule.name: irregardless (regardless)
rule.example: Irregardless of what he says, do it!
rule.message: 在日常和非正式写作中'Irregardless'是可以被接受的。在正式的文体中，应该使用 regardless .

rule.name: Sentence starting with 'And' or 'But'
rule.example: And yes, it shows a lack of style to start a sentence with 'and'.
Yes, it shows a lack of style to start a sentence with 'and'.
But it is not a great writing style to start a sentence with 'but'.
It is not a great writing style to start a sentence with 'but'.
rule.message: 虽然不是完全意义上的错误，但从文体上说，虽然不常见，但'\2'仅用在句首，体现出戏剧性的效果。

rule.name: Number starting a sentence
rule.example: 12 soldiers were killed!
Twelve soldiers were killed!
rule.message: 句首的数字应该写成英文单词。

rule.name: Word order: 'Hopefully' starting a sentence
rule.example: Hopefully, this will be a great grammar checker.
The prisoner thought hopefully about the prospect for escape.
rule.message: 许多语法书建议句子不要以'hopefully'开头。

rule.name: Readability: Three nouns in a row
rule.example: The security protection software we offer is the state-of-the art achievement.
The security software we offer is the state-of-the art achievement.
rule.message: 你连续使用了三个名词，这将会降低句子的可读性。可以考虑重新组织下句子。

rule.name: Style: 'possible' after 'possibility'
rule.example: I did not have a possibility to check for possible errors.
A possibility for possible errors exist.
You should remove all possibilities for these possible errors.
I did not have a chance to check for possible errors.
I did not have a possibility to check for errors.
Einstein published an article in 'Physikalische Zeitschrift' that proposed the possibility of stimulated emission, the physical process that makes possible the maser and the laser.
There is a possible possibility that errors exist.
rule.message: 不好的文体。在'\2'的前面用这样的单词chance or opportunity . 或者留下'\1'去掉'\2'.

rulegroup.name: capitalize proper names, geographic terms, historic episodes...

rule.message: Capitalize specific, well-defined geographical regions:
rule.example: She lived several years in south America.
With the reunification of West and east Germany, the Federal Republic of Germany became known simply as 'Germany'.
The term NATO stands for the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.
Go south three blocks and then turn left.
The west coast of Scotland is rainy this time of year.
Albania is a country in Southeastern Europe.
The British Isles and North-Western Europe.

rule.message: Capitalize holidays.
rule.example: What did you do on Valentine's day last year?
What are your plans for President's Day?

rule.message: Capitalize holidays.
rule.example: What did you do on Veterans day last year?

rule.message: Capitalize specific historic events, episodes, and eras.
rule.example: How many people died in world war II?

rule.message: Capitalize specific historic events, episodes, and eras.
rule.example: The middle ages is one of the three major periods in the most enduring scheme for analysing European history.

rule.message: Capitalize specific, well-defined geographical places.
rule.example: The cape of good hope is a rocky headland on the Atlantic coast of the Cape Peninsula, South Africa.

rule.message: Capitalize specific, well-defined geographical places.
rule.example: Since 1914, cape cod has been separated from the mainland by the Cape Cod Canal.

rule.message: Capitalize The, if it refers to 'The Hague' (city on the western coast of the Netherlands)
rule.example: Some of the most prosperous neighbourhoods of the Netherlands can be found in the Hague.
When did the Hague Congress take place?

rule.name: 'also' at the end of the sentence
rule.example: You will also buy some eggs.
You will buy some eggs also.
rule.message: 'Also'不用在句子结尾。用 as well .

rule.example: It is possible that the sky is blue.
It is also possible that the sky is blue.
The sky might be blue.
rule.message: 改被动语态为主动语态? 例如: "It is possible that the sky is blue." 可以改为"The sky might be blue".

rule.example: He is said to have been happy.
He is said to have not been happy.
The people said that he was happy.
He is not thought to have been happy.
He was not thought to have been happy.
rule.message: 改被动语态为主动语态? 例如: "It is possible that the sky is blue." 可以改为"The sky might be blue".

rule.example: He is said to be happy.
People say that he is happy.
rule.message: 改被动语态为主动语态? 例如: "It is possible that the sky is blue." 可以改为"The sky might be blue".

rule.example: He insisted that red should be used.
He insisted that red be used.
He insisted on using red.
rule.message: 改被动语态为主动语态? 例如: "It is possible that the sky is blue." 可以改为"The sky might be blue".

rule.example: Her work will have been finished by tonight.
Her work will not have been finished by tonight.
She will have her work finished by tonight.
rule.message: 改被动语态为主动语态? 例如: "It is possible that the sky is blue." 可以改为"The sky might be blue".

rule.example: A cake is being baked by him by tonight.
He is baking a cake.
A cake is also being baked by him by tonight.
A cake was also being baked by him by tonight.
A dozen cookies were also being baked by him by tonight.
rule.message: 改被动语态为主动语态? 例如: "It is possible that the sky is blue." 可以改为"The sky might be blue".

rule.example: Instruments are played by her.
Instruments were played by her.
Instruments are not played by her.
John was given a book by her.
She plays instruments.
rule.message: 改被动语态为主动语态? 例如: "It is possible that the sky is blue." 可以改为"The sky might be blue".

rule.name: May 20001 (May 2001)
rule.message: Did you really mean year \2? Or maybe ?
rule.example: I will go to Holland in May 20014.

rule.name: 'to both ...' with more than two items
rule.example: It allows us to both grow, focus, and flourish.
It allows us to both grow a lot, focus, and flourish.
It allows us to both grow a lot, focus some, and flourish.
It allows us to both grow and focus, and later flourish.
rule.message: 'both'通常用在两者之间。
The date \3 \4 \5 is not a {day}, but a {realDay}.
rule.example: IGD Convention - Monday, 7 October 2014
IGD Convention - Mon, 7 October 2014
IGD Convention - Mo, 7 October 2014
IGD Convention - Monday, 7 Oct 2014
IGD Convention - Tuesday, 7 October 2014
IGD Convention - Tuesday, 7 Oct 2014

rule.message: The date \3 \4, \6 is not a {day}, but a {realDay}.
rule.example: IGD Convention - Monday, October 7, 2014
IGD Convention - Mon, October 7, 2014
IGD Convention - Mo, October 7, 2014
IGD Convention - Wednesday, October 7, 2014
IGD Convention - Thursday, October 7, 2014
IGD Convention - Friday, October 7, 2014
IGD Convention - Saturday, October 7, 2014
IGD Convention - Sunday, October 7, 2014
IGD Convention - Sunday, Oct 7, 2014
IGD Convention - Tuesday, October 7, 2014
IGD Convention - Tuesday, Oct 7, 2014

rule.message: The date \3/\5/\7 is not a {day}, but a {realDay}.
rule.example: IGD Convention 2014 - Monday, 31/10/2014
IGD Convention 2014 - Friday, 31/10/2014
IGD Convention 2014 - Monday, 10/09/2014
IGD Convention 2014 - Monday, 9/10/2014

rule.message: The date \3/\5/\7 is not a {day}, but a {realDay}.
rule.example: IGD Convention 2014 - Monday, 10/31/2014
IGD Convention 2014 - Friday, 10/31/2014
IGD Convention 2014 - Monday, 10/09/2014
IGD Convention 2014 - Monday, 9/10/2014

rule.message: The date \3 (YYYY-MM-DD) is not a {day}, but a {realDay}.
rule.example: IGD Convention 2014 - Monday, 2014-10-31
IGD Convention 2014 - Friday, 2014-10-31
It happened on November 31, 2014.
