rule.message: 在英语中，'semester'指的是学术机构中的一个学期，即一学年分为两学期。这在英国和爱尔兰是很少见的，在那里，学年通常分为三个学期。在其他情况下，“学期”很少使用六个月。试试: half , six months , six-month period .

In English, 'trimester' is used in medicine to refer to any of the three periods of approximately three months into which pregnancy is divided. It is rarely used to refer to three-month periods in other contexts. Alternatives: quarter, three months, three-month period.
rule.example: … were given during 2011 and in the first trimester of 2012.
The course duration is four trimesters.
… were given during 2011 and in the first quarter of 2012.
… were given during 2011 and in the first three months of 2012.

rule.name: service
rule.message: At the Commission (but not usually at the Court), the term 'service' is widely used with a meaning akin to 'department'. Alternatives: staff, department.
rule.example: The services of the Commission's Accounting Officer carried out a…
The staff of the Commission's Accounting Officer carried out a…
In agreement with the service of the Commission, the group…
In agreement with the Commission, the group…
When you service the vehicles…

rule.name: shall
rule.message: The use of 'shall' in the third person (he/she/it/they) is archaic and is only used in legislation or contracts or direct quotes from them (in inverted commas). It should never be used when paraphrasing legislation or quoting it indirectly. Alternatives: must, should, is/are, is to/are to, can, may.
rule.example: It shall also include…
The members of the board shall act independently.
It must also include…
Shall we go to London tomorrow?
We shall be in London next week.

rule.name: sickness insurance
rule.message: As the correct term is health insurance, presumably one would take out 'sickness insurance' if one wanted to stay in bad health. Alternatives: health insurance.
rule.example: … from an establishment with which the insured person's sickness insurance fund has an agreement.

rule.name: so-called
rule.message: This is a risky term to use; although some dictionaries allow the meaning 'commonly known as', others, like the Collins dictionary, emphasise that its use casts doubt on the veracity of the term it introduces = 'called (in the speaker's opinion, wrongly) by that name'. Often, 'so-called' is superfluous and the other term can stand alone. In other cases we can say 'known as' or 'this is called'.
rule.example: The so-called transitional system for the application of VAT…
…, designed for monitoring the respiratory and anaesthetic gases of a patient under medical treatment (so-called 'Gas Analyser Module')'
The transitional system for the application of VAT…
…, designed for monitoring the respiratory and anaesthetic gases of a patient under medical treatment ('Gas Analyser Module').

rule.message: 'Suppress' is a bit like 'incite' in that it is often related to violence. It is also often combined with the adverbs 'savagely' or forcibly'. Indeed, the first definition of suppress in the Oxford online dictionary is 'forcibly put an end to'. You can suppress a revolt or an uprising, but you cannot suppress a bus stop. Alternatives: abolish, cancel, withdraw.
rule.example: … to suppress the fees at the start of 2015.
If the authority suppresses the fees…
… to abolish the fees at the start of 2015.

rule.message: 'Suppress' is a bit like 'incite' in that it is often related to violence. It is also often combined with the adverbs 'savagely' or forcibly'. Indeed, the first definition of suppress in the Oxford online dictionary is 'forcibly put an end to'. You can suppress a revolt or an uprising, but you cannot suppress a bus stop. Alternatives: abolished, cancelled, withdrew, withdrawn.
rule.example: … where fees were suppressed at the start of 2015.
The authority suppressed the fees at the start of 2015.
… where fees were withdrawn at the start of 2015.
The authority withdrew the fees at the start of 2015.

rule.message: 'Suppress' is a bit like 'incite' in that it is often related to violence. It is also often combined with the adverbs 'savagely' or forcibly'. Indeed, the first definition of suppress in the Oxford online dictionary is 'forcibly put an end to'. You can suppress a revolt or an uprising, but you cannot suppress a bus stop. Alternatives: abolishing, cancelling, withdrawing.
rule.example: If you are suppressing the fees, …
… if suppressing the fees is necessary.
If you are withdrawing the fees, …

rule.message: 'Suppress' is a bit like 'incite' in that it is often related to violence. Alternatives: abolition, cancellation, withdrawal.
rule.example: Furthermore, the suppression of inpatient fees from 2014…

rule.name: third country
rule.message: The USA is one country, Canada is another, and Ireland is a third. The USA could sign an agreement with Canada to exclude a third country (e.g. Ireland) from their territorial waters (for fishing, for example). In EU texts, however, this term is widely used to mean 'countries outside the European Union', and sometimes 'countries outside whatever grouping of countries we are talking about'. Use: non-member (or state), non-Schengen (or state), outside the EU/EEA etc.

example.correction: non-member country|non-Schengen country|country outside the EU

rule.example: The standard values for imports from a third country are…

example.correction: non-member countries|non-Schengen countries|countries outside the EU

rule.example: He has a Schengen visa but he is not allowed to work in third countries.
The standard values for imports from a non-member state are…
He has a Schengen visa but he is not allowed to work in non-Schengen countries.
He has a Schengen visa but he is not allowed to work in non-EU countries.

rule.message: This is one of a series of gerunds used creatively but incorrectly as countable nouns, which is not generally possible in English. Training in English is a process (the process of being trained) and it cannot be used as a synonym for a '(training) course'. Alternatives: course (language course/I am on a course/I am doing a course), workshop (attending a workshop), presentation, talk etc.
rule.example: … ICT (including for the purpose of a training).

rule.message: This is one of a series of gerunds used creatively but incorrectly as countable nouns, which is not generally possible in English. Training in English is a process (the process of being trained) and it cannot be used as a synonym for a '(training) course'. Alternatives: courses (language course/I am on a course/I am doing a course), workshops (attending a workshop), presentation, talk etc.
rule.example: … ICT (including for the purpose of trainings).

rule.name: transmit
rule.message: 'Transmit' normally refers to radio or television, data, and, possibly, the sadly defunct, Morse code. When sending something by letter, email or fax, we normally say 'send'. If we are sending something on that has been sent to us, we say 'forward' or 'send on' rather than 'retransmit'. Alternatives: send, forward.
rule.example: When the Court transmits its draft report…
The Court would thus be required to transmit its draft report on the same day that the Commission is required…
Each Member State shall retransmit to the NEAFC Secretary reports and messages…
When the Court sends its draft report…

rule.message: In English 'to transpose' means 'to put in a different order' or 'to transfer to a different place or context'. Alternatives: incorporate (into national law).
rule.example: … which transpose Chapter 3 of Title XI of Directive 2006/112/EC.
… which incorporate Chapter 3 of Title XI of Directive 2006/112/EC.

rule.message: In English 'to transpose' means 'to put in a different order' or 'to transfer to a different place or context'. Alternatives: incorporation (into national law).
rule.example: The transposition of Chapter 3 of Title XI of Directive 2006/112/EC…
The incorporation of Chapter 3 of Title XI of Directive 2006/112/EC…

rule.message: 'Transverse' (meaning 'lying across; situated or lying crosswise or athwart') has 223 BNC entries, but these nearly all refer to the fields of medicine ('transverse colon', being the most common), natural science and mechanical engineering. Transverse is not used figuratively. Alternatives: cross-cutting, inter + something (interdepartmental, interministerial); sometimes just 'broad' or 'general'. Some rephrasing might be needed ('across the board', for example).
rule.example: The activities are transverse and apply to all…
Transverse Activities (TAs) means actions with relevance across several ITDs…
The activities are general and apply to all…

rule.message: 'Transversal' (meaning 'intersecting a system of lines') occurs three times in the British National Corpus and 709 times in EUR-Lex. This is, in itself, an indication that something is amiss. Transversal is not used figuratively. Alternatives: cross-cutting, inter + something (interdepartmental, interministerial); sometimes just 'broad' or 'general'
rule.example: Conclusions of the Council on a transversal approach to youth policy.
To give priority to digital technology in a transversal manner…
Conclusions of the Council on a broad approach to youth policy.

rule.name: travels
rule.message: Trip is countable, travel is not, at least not in its normal meaning of 'the action of travelling'. Alternatives: trips, travel (singular).
rule.example: The consent form for travels in and out of the Schengen area…
The findings of the report concerning Members' travels show that…
The consent form for trips in and out of the Schengen area…
If he travels for many hours…

rule.name: treatment [data]
rule.message: We normally speak of data processing, not data treatment. Alternatives: data processing.
rule.example: The significant efforts undertaken in data treatment and methodological developments…
Eurostat will continue its efforts to speed up the data treatment procedures.

rule.name: valorise|valorize
rule.message: 'To valorise' means 'to fix and maintain an artificial price for (a commodity) by governmental action'. In EU texts, however, it is often used to mean 'to assign a value to' or to 'make the most of'. Alternatives: increase the value of, give a value to, enhance, make the most of, accentuate, upgrade, put to good use.
rule.example: The work of the Agency was valorised for both the public and the private sectors.
… only those cultivation practices which seek to valorize almost the whole of the product cultivated should be accepted.
The work of the Agency was assigned a value for both the public and the private sectors.

rule.name: verifications
rule.message: Verification means 'the process of establishing the truth, accuracy, or validity of something'. It is an uncountable noun and does not normally have a plural. We do not, therefore, perform or 'do' (or even make) verifications in English. Alternatives: checks.
rule.example: To increase the effectiveness of its on-the-spot verifications of the Member States' statistical reports…
No ex post verifications were carried out for any transactions made after 2008.

rule.name: visa
rule.message: Visa is misused to render not only 'approval', but also the act of giving approval. In English, a visa is generally 'an official authorisation appended to a passport, permitting entry into and travel within a particular country or region'. It is also the name of a credit card. Alternatives: approval, endorsement, to approve, to endorse.
rule.example: The centralised ex-ante visa performed by the Financial Controller, …
The Finance Section has to visa all transactions before they can be authorised.
… the ex-ante visa of the Delegation would be suspended unless…
The centralised ex-ante approval performed by the Financial Controller, …
